12/ This reduces latency between the route calculation and the transaction landing time, which greatly reduces slippage. Declarative Swaps also reduce the likelihood of sandwiching when routing through Conditional Liquidity DEXs like Clearpools, which offer tighter spreads to

11/ Declarative Swaps, built with Jito bundles, offer a quote to the Solana trader at signature time, but recalculate the route immediately before the transaction lands on the network, while adhering to the promised quote.
10/ Declarative Swaps trade through existing sources of Solana liquidity, as well as new conditional liquidity DEXs, like Clearpools.

urls.title: DFlow - Intelligent Trade Execution on Solana
urls.description: The Trading API powering tens of billions in transacted value on Solana. For traders, applications, and financial institutions.

data.text:
9/ Now onto Declarative Swaps!

Declarative Swaps are a new trading primitive offered to Solana traders that allow traders to declare an intention to swap, and then use a Segmenter to execute the swap.

Declarative Swaps are live on https://t.co/nw63YhFNag today!

8/ We‚Äôre also excited to announce Clearpools, the first Conditional Liquidity DEX.

Clearpools is an open-source fork of Orca, a leading DEX on Solana. Clearpools liquidity will offer a tighter spread to non-toxic order flow, while widening out for toxic order flow. https://t.co/3650izoSHt

7/ Segmenters that attract the most order flow capture a portion of the delta between the tightened spread and general spread.

The DFlow Aggregator will serve as the first Segmenter. If interested in becoming a Segmenter, please fill out the intake form: https://t.co/jWh0fPaGeu
6/ Initially, the set of Segmenters will be chosen via a reputation system, and progressively decentralized into a permissionless election and rejection system.

5/ Segmenters will compete against each other in order to reduce the probability of adverse selection to LPs. DEXs ultimately control the allowance that a Segmenter has to tighten to non-toxic order flow. https://t.co/gzyub4XB0R
4/ Order flow that is routed through Segmenters is able to trade at relatively tighter spreads, proportional to the Segmenter‚Äôs belief of the non-toxicity of the order flow. https://t.co/3b5Ta94kFi
3/ CL is powered by a new class of market actors known as Segmenters. DEXs express the tightest they are willing to quote to compete for non-toxic flow to Segmenters.

1/ Today, we are delighted to release Declarative Swaps, and Conditional Liquidity (CL), a new LP mechanism that allows Solana DEXs to JIT adjust their spread based on the toxicity of order flow.

Read more! üßµ https://t.co/BqeAAE3TRG

2/ DEXs tighten their spread in order to attract more order flow. However, by doing so, they increase risk of adverse selection by sophisticated takers.

CL is an LP mechanism that enables just-in-time adjustment of DEX spreads based on the expected toxicity of the order flow.

üí• new swap interface just dropped üí•

[11] This new, DFlow-powered, market structure will be wrapped into a next-generation aggregator we‚Äôre calling the Segmenter, and made available to users through the DFlow app - an effortless, mobile-first trading experience.
[10] One of the main use-cases of the protocol will be allowing DEXs and liquidity providers to specialize their on-chain behavior based on the toxicity of order flow.
[9] The upcoming DFlow protocol is a general solution that allows any on-chain program to specialize their behavior based on off-chain information sourced through decentralized information markets.

[8] Today, DEXs and liquidity providers aren‚Äôt equipped with decentralized tools that help them avoid toxic order flow.

Enter the DFlow protocol.

[7] This is the reason why, despite much more trading volume and heightened interest in Solana, the amount of liquidity hasn‚Äôt increased significantly. 

Toxic order flow is a constant dampening effect on the arrival of more good-for-community liquidity providers.
[6] However, on DEXs, the game is rigged. Liquidity providers, especially LPs in AMMs, face a market structural disadvantage that prevents through from intelligently avoiding toxic order flow.

[5] A good liquidity provider must be intelligent about how they quote in the face of the possibility of toxic order flow.

If unable to be proactive about revising quotes, or widening or tightening based on toxicity, liquidity providers will suffer losses.

[4] Toxic order flow confers a cost to liquidity providers by making it difficult for those liquidity providers to capture a positive bid-ask spread. 

Avoiding toxic order flow is normally part of the game that liquidity providers have to play in order to capture a spread.

Gm! We have officially crossed a quarter of a million user signups for DFlow early access.

Let‚Äôs chat a bit about what we‚Äôre building, why it‚Äôs unique, and what Solana users should be looking forward to.

üßµ https://t.co/wNpgMEUib3
[3] Providing liquidity on-chain, through a DEX, is difficult for a large number of reasons, that we‚Äôll refer to under the umbrella term of ‚Äútoxic order flow‚Äù.

[2] Liquidity providers on Solana are providing a service to the community. Without liquidity, you can‚Äôt trade tokens.

DEXs are where liquidity is housed, by either market makers in decentralized CLOBs or through retail LPs, institutional funds, and more in AMMs.

The AdaptiveBBO is the decentralized analogue to the NBBO in the stock market. 

The AdaptiveBBO aims to serve as the standard for best-execution in crypto, by enforcing market makers to fill within the best bid and offer. 

This means better prices and more savings üòé

9/ Check out the blog for more details!

https://t.co/zKq43yhuh7

8/ DFlow Swap uses the AdaptiveBBO to bring better prices and more savings to retail users.

You worked hard for your money ‚Äì keep them by trading on https://t.co/ITIGNTcxdM!
7/ It may not seem much but over time, price improvements result in significant cost savings to users in aggregate.

6/ Let's say you want to buy 1 ETH and there are exchanges A, B, C and D:

A quotes $3,000.25
B quotes $3,001.50
C quotes $3,000.75
D quotes $3,001.25

The AdaptiveBBO will quote $2999.75 by finding the best price (Exchange A) and applying a tighter spread, saving you $0.50.

5/ DFlow protocol is a user of the AdaptiveBBO and users trading through applications powered by the DFlow protocol trade at, or within, the AdaptiveBBO.

This means market makers can only offer to buy at a higher price than the bid or sell at a lower price than the offer.
4/ The AdaptiveBBO currently sources prices from both Coinbase and Binance, with Uniswap coming next ‚Äì three of the leading centralized and decentralized exchanges.

1/ Introducing the AdaptiveBBO as a new benchmark for execution quality in crypto!

Users often do not realize how much in transaction costs they are paying because most of the costs are implicit. They are only realized after the trade. https://t.co/VjXy3lvszm

3/ Trading costs can be represented by the effective spread ‚Äì a proxy for slippage, MEV and fees. 

The AdaptiveBBO algorithm is a sophisticated graph traversal that attempts to optimize the users paying the least spread possible.
2/ Simple math: if users are charged 50 bps in swap fees and LP fees up front and another 50 bps in slippage after the fact, users are paying 1% every time they trade.

Order flow auctions are a way to signal to market makers the quality of order flow.

Signaling conveys information about the intents behind a batch of buy or sell orders by revealing certain attributes.

Case 1: $250,000 sell order. 

Case 2: $2,000 sell order.

Just by looking https://t.co/pTc0gT60Yx

10/ This is just one side of the benefits of DFlow auctions. There is more to be said about how auctions, via order flow segmentation, provide better prices to retail traders. 

More to come later.

9/ DFlow allows both parties to use information in a symbiotic way.

Market makers are paying to not be on the less informed side.
